Food for Thought: A programming language that speaks to designers

Author
Sara Breselor
Published
March 16, 2015
Reading Time
2 minutes

Every Thursday in Palo Alto, IDEO’s Digital Shop hosts an informal lunchtime presentation by someone who is using code to create something surprising, useful, or generally awesome. Colleagues from all around IDEO gather for a meal and leave with a week’s worth of ideas to chew on. For Labs, we’ve asked some recent speakers to highlight a quick insight or tool they’d like to share.

Guest: Scott Murray
Specs: Assistant professor of design at the University of San Francisco, code artist, D3 expert, and contributor to the Processing language.

Scott Murray is endlessly excited about using code as a tool for visual explorations of all kinds, from fine art to interactive data visualizations, but his students aren’t always quite so jazzed about the idea of programming. “They’re used to Photoshop and Illustrator, chopping up pictures and vectors,” he says. “Coding moves them into a totally different working environment.”

It’s Murray’s job to pry open students’ minds to not only the languages of code but also to a new way of thinking—a developer’s approach to solving problems and building things. To this end, he’s helping to continue the development of Processing language, which is tailored specifically to the task of teaching designers and artists to code. “There are pedagogical tools embedded in the language itself,” he says, like the use of familiar terms such as “stroke” and “fill” as well as processes that help students think like developers when approaching the craft of design. “For me, design is all about systems—not creating an image, but a system that, when applied, results in an effective solution,” Murray says. “Processing, as a teaching tool, forces students to think beyond the output or image they want to create and describe the system they’re making and what it needs to do.”

Processing gives designers new tools and expands their design thinking. It’s free, open source, and available to all at processing.org.

To see some examples of what experts are doing with Processing, check out this exhibition site. (Murray particularly likes “Keyfleas” — above.)

To get a sense of what beginners can do with the language, visit openprocessing.org and browse through the sketches.

If you’re itching to get your hands dirty, go straight to this collection of short, prototypical online programs that explore the basics of programming with Processing.

Check out the complete version of Scott Murray’s New Year greeting card pictured in the header to this post here. 
Sara Breselor

I am a writer and editor based in San Francisco. I’m a regular contributor to Wired, Make, Communication Arts, and the Harper’s Weekly Review, and I’m the editor of the IDEO Labs website. I have worked as associate editor at Communication Arts, assistant editor at Harper’s, and researcher at Wired. I’m always looking for new projects involving culture, books, technology, and cool people. Please contact me at sara.breselor@gmail.com.

2 thoughts on “Food for Thought: A programming language that speaks to designers”

  1. Dominique Kenens March 27, 2015 at 3:28 am

    Problem remains: Processing, while being a cool implement to create imagery, is basically JavaScript with the serial numbers filed off.

    If one really wants to bridge the gap between artist and coder, we need an interface to manipulate code as if it were blocks of wood, dashes of paint, or leaves of paper.

    An objectified view of logic structures, as readable as a painting (instead of a book), close to how the better WYSIWYG web editors handle certain code.

    Meanwhile, coding has remained at nearly a standstill, compared to f.i. the graphical user interfaces of art apps.

    Coding apps rely upon syntax coloring, code collapsing, line numbering, hyperlinks and indents, while the languages themselves rely upon antiquated concepts as “closing braces”, parentheses and obtuse vocabulary (ask an English major about the meaning of “obtuse” and “void”, and chances are “void” will give you a definition far removed from its “code vocabulary”).

    Todays 3D/HD/interactive/graphical possibilities could be applied so code cantruly be “nested” inside eachother, variables are “fed” into subroutines, and results are “collected” and passed on to other blocks of code, in a fashion that gives code architecture a new meaning.

    Until then, true coding will remain too daunting a task to the truly visual thinker, or (as is my case) necessitates a costly, lengthy and slow devotion to multiple fields at once, which is not that simple a feat…

  2. Mark Edwards March 27, 2015 at 8:04 am

    Totally agree with you Dominique. I’ve been learning to program for ~25 years and have only produced one small application I am proud of (in Director).

    Adobe’s GoLive used a “rope” to connect objects. Why isn’t this wonderful UI object used in every IDE? Inputs and outputs, is programming anything beyond this?

    Apple’s Quartz Composer is helpful (especially for the visual thinker), but still requires Xcode/Interface Builder to build an app with an interface.
